conclusion: Identify the geometry and given data: inner radius R, outer radius sqrt(2)R, refractive index n, radius of incident light beam R.
Apply Snell's Law at the inner surface: n1 sin(theta_i) = n2 sin(theta_r), with n1 = 1 and n2 = n.
Determine the critical angle for total internal reflection: sin(theta_c) = 1/n.
Calculate the angle of incidence at the outer surface: angle of incidence at outer surface is same as angle of refraction at inner surface, theta_r.
Use geometry to relate angles and radii: light rays travel radially outward, radius of circular boundary determined by grazing point.
Determine the radius of the circular boundary: radius r found using relationship between inner and outer radii and angle of refraction.
Final calculation: r = sqrt(2)R sin(theta_r), and since sin(theta_r) = 1/n, r = sqrt(2)R/n.
Conclusion: radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface is sqrt(2)R/n.
